text:
You can use less salt… like 10g salt per 1kg (~2lbs) cabbage if you have everything else in check.  IIRC iodized salt is problematic for the lacto-fermentation so I've been using Himalayan pink salt without problems.

.2-3 weeks seems to be a good general timeframe, after that I put in the fridge for months… actually have a few jars that are about 1.5 years old and the flavours are now so complex.  Some caraway and juniper berries add a nice touch, and red cabbage is really nice too﻿

author: sixyears

text:
Freezer bag works fine. You can crush it in the bag. Just squeeze out the CO2 every day. I let it do it's thing on my nightstand 3 weeks is the sweet spot.

Easy classic saurcroutRecipe: Fill bottom of large pot with small potatoes.
Smear on a cup of redered fat (I use duck fat), season with only pepper.
Lay on about 2 or 3 inches of kraut.
Fill up to almost top of kraut with equal parts chicken stock and sweet white wine or strong beer. Throw your meat on top (I like german sausage and smoked pork chops.
Cover and let it simmer on the stove for 3 hours.
Let it cool a bit then serve.
Delicious, hearty, creamy and tart.﻿

author: Jamie Faith

text:
Try russian recepie  of sauerkraut 
- сabbage (chunks 15x5mm or so, your  chunks are good too!) 10kg
- largly grated сarrot 2-3kg
- coasely ground solt 0.2-0.25kg
Lightly mix producs together with solt. Do not (never, never, never) crush or squeeze cabbage to get juice! This juise is the best part, try to keep in inside the cabbage chunks!
Put all in 12-15L faience pot or (the best way) wooden barrel, cover with dish and put clean stone as oppression. You need to keep it under press (3L glass jar with water, like your is OK for 10kg of rpodets) 
Keep 1+ week to ferment  at room temperature about 20-22C.
Make several holes to the bottom  each day to let CO2 gases go out or cabbage become bitter. Let gases out once or twice a day.
Never, never massage or press cabbage  to press juice. Solt will make enought juice, much more you need to ferment and cover.
Never freеze Sauerkraut . Keep upto zero geegree (+1C-5C) for months! You can freeze it. Mostly we do freeze it outside and keep frozen all winter (Frost and snow in Siberia for free). Once cabbage is frozen it become worse and you have to keep it frozen. Sometimes we it iced.

Lemony sour, crunchy, juicy, ambertransparent cabbage chunks! 
Sometimes we put  green sour appales to the barrel to ferment with cabbage (not regular way).. or sometimes thyme seed a little bit. But mostly, it is just cabbage, carrot, solt.
We never add garlic or mustard seeds. 
The best way to serve as salad: Sauerkraut with cowberry or wild cranberries, onion and sunflower oil...
The best way for soup - shchi!

We, russains/siberians, are best in sauerkraud. we do it for ages! I do 20-30kg each winter for my family for winter. it is traditional food. (uhhhh! Bitter cowberry, sauerkraut, sweet fresh apples chunks  - the best winter salad)
Write me if interested. I can show.﻿

author: Kuesa

text: You know there is a better way to make your Sauerkraut. Take your wide mouth quart mason jars pack them with cabbage , add 1TBS canning salt, 1TBS cider vinegar you don't have to mix it in the cabbage,  top them up with cold water and then put the ring lids on. Not to tight you want the gas to be able to escape! You then place 6-8 jars in the bottom of a clean 50 gal plastic trash can. You then place another layer, careful sitting the second layer on the first layer  and finale place 3 rd layer of jars on top of the second layer.  You should have 3 layer with about 24-36 jars in your 50 gal trash can.  The next step is to fill the trash can with water so that it covers the jars I like to fill the water up till it just covers each layer as you load them in put the trash can lid on . Place it in cool place and leave it alone for 21 days. Just walk away.    21 days later  pull the jars out, tighten the lids down and place them in cool dark place. It will be good for about 8-12 months the longer it sits the sour it gets. My grand mother taught me how to make it when I was about 16. You don't have worry about skimming anything or make sure the cabbage stay under the juice. Once in awhile you will get a little scum on the surface of the water in the trash can,  just skim it off the surface of the water.﻿

author: sina yyy

text: That's why Brad makes sure to push the cabbage underneath the "water" surface. As long as the cabbage is submerged in the salty brine, it will not mold. However, as it bubbles up, some cabbage may get up over the surface and that's when the bacteria attacks. At least that's how I understand it... fermenting is a funny thing﻿

author: Gavin Hays

text: There is a lot of controversy over molds. I've been in very heated discussions in both fermentation groups and charcuterie groups. Charcuterie gurus seem to be a little more comfortable with itbut fermenters really freak out and discard their product. Much of the same molds are present in both products but mycelium do grow down onto the substrate they grow on sooo I say scrape it off too if no bad flavors are produced.  We need to find out what molds present themselves and find out if they produce mycotoxins or not. Surely you guys have enough money to find out for us. I'd love for youto explore the science behind this problem we encounter and find out if out is safe or could be harmful to is. Thanks Brad for the enjoyable and informative clips﻿
author: Randall Burger

text:
I tried to make sauerkraut once a couple of months ago.  Stupidly I tried to make a big batch first go.  When I went to check if it was done there was a huge blob of mould floating but partly submerged in the top.  it smelt real nasty too.  I threw the lot away, but under the mould it smelt just like sauerkraut.  I still threw it though 'cos the mould was really really nasty.
With charcuterie, it's pretty simple.  if the mould if fluffy, threw it away. If it's just flat on the surface it should be fine.﻿
author: carpy1970

text: We made and distributed sauerkraut. I worked with a fermentation specialist who was also one of my inspectors at the health department. He helped me set up all of my protocols.  Molds happen and were not a concern in our operation.﻿
